questions.text: A 31-year-old man comes to the emergency department because of chest pain for the last 3 hours. He describes the pain as a sharp, substernal chest pain that radiates to the right shoulder; he says “Please help me. I'm having a heart attack.” He has been admitted to the hospital twice over the past week for evaluation of shortness of breath and abdominal pain but left the hospital the following day on both occasions. The patient does not smoke or drink alcohol but is a known user of intravenous heroin. He has been living in a homeless shelter for the past 2 weeks after being evicted from his apartment for failure to pay rent. His temperature is 37.6°C (99.6°F), pulse is 90/min, respirations are 18/min, and blood pressure is 125/85 mm Hg. The patient seems anxious and refuses a physical examination of his chest. His cardiac troponin I concentration is 0.01 ng/mL. An ECG shows a normal sinus rhythm with nonspecific ST-T wave changes. While the physician is planning to discharge the patient, the patient reports numbness in his arm and insists on being admitted to the ward. On the following day, the patient leaves the hospital without informing the physician or the nursing staff. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Individuals with a functional neurological symptom disorder experience neurological symptoms (e.g., numbness, weakness, tremors, pseudoseizures) that are not consistent with any known neurologic disorder and often follow an acute stressor. However, non-neurological symptoms such as substernal chest pain, shortness of breath, or abdominal pain would not be expected. Moreover, unlike this patient, individuals with functional neurological symptom disorder exhibit symptoms in the absence of an obvious external reward.

B) INCORRECT:

Individuals with factitious disorder intentionally feign the symptoms of an illness (including induction of injury or disease through self-harm); however, the motive is the emotional support or sympathy (internal reward) obtained by playing the “sick role” and not an external reward (e.g., housing). Moreover, unlike this patient, individuals with a factitious disorder are usually cooperative during their medical evaluation.

C) CORRECT:

Malingering is characterized by the conscious feigning of symptoms (often false or grossly exaggerated) in order to obtain an external reward (e.g., housing, time off from work, narcotics, avoidance of jail time). Individuals are typically uncooperative during their medical evaluation out of fear of being caught, such as this man who refuses a physical examination of the chest. Symptoms usually improve once the desired benefit is obtained. Malingering is not classified as a mental disorder.

D) INCORRECT:

Individuals with illness anxiety disorder often have a history of frequent visits to physicians, hospitalization, and inconclusive diagnostic tests. However, this disorder is characterized by significant anxiety over health and persistent fear (≥ 6 months) of having or developing an illness despite having no or only mild physical symptoms. This patient has intermittent symptoms that started one week ago and he is likely motivated by an external reward, which is not consistent with illness anxiety disorder.

E) INCORRECT:

Individuals with somatic symptom disorder report multiple somatic symptoms (e.g., chest pain, shortness of breath, abdominal pain) and often have a history of frequent visits to physicians, hospitalizations, and inconclusive diagnostic tests. However, the symptoms of somatic symptom disorder persist for a period of ≥ 6 months, occur in the absence of a motive, and cause constant excessive distress to the patient. This patient has only had symptoms intermittently over the past week, is likely motivated by an external reward, and does not appear to be excessively concerned by his symptoms as he left the hospital on multiple occasions without informing the staff.
questions.hint: This patient is most likely seeking an external reward.

questions.text: A 34-year-old woman comes to the physician requesting prenatal care. For the past 2 months, she has had increasing breast tenderness, nausea, 3-kg (6.6-lb) weight gain, and urinary frequency. She is not sure about the date of her last menstrual period. She has been trying to conceive with her husband since she stopped taking oral contraceptives 6 months ago; she was happy to tell him last week that she is pregnant. Her temperature is 37.2°C (99°F), pulse is 100/min, and blood pressure is 110/60 mm Hg. Physical examination shows mild, nontender abdominal enlargement. The cervical os is closed. A urine pregnancy test is negative. Transvaginal ultrasonography shows no abnormalities. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Patients with delusion of pregnancy have a fixed, false belief that they are pregnant. There is insufficient evidence to determine whether this patient's beliefs are fixed. However, patients with a delusion of pregnancy will lack physical signs of pregnancy and usually have a history of psychosis; there is no known history of illness in this patient and she presents with physical signs of early pregnancy (breast tenderness, nausea, weight gain, urinary frequency, mild abdominal enlargement).

B) CORRECT:

The combination of this patient's belief that she is pregnant with physical signs of early pregnancy (breast tenderness, nausea, weight gain, urinary frequency, mild abdominal enlargement), along with negative confirmatory testing (undetectable β-hCG, empty uterus on ultrasound) is consistent with pseudocyesis. This condition is more common among women who want to get pregnant and have a history of several prior failed attempts. She should be gently informed that she is not pregnant and provided with counseling and therapy if needed.

C) INCORRECT:

Malingering patients usually present with vague complaints that are inconsistent with a medical diagnosis in a conscious attempt to deceive the medical system to attain some secondary gain/reward. Since this patient presents with actual signs of pregnancy, another condition is more likely.

D) INCORRECT:

Pregnancy can manifest with breast tenderness, abdominal enlargement, nausea, and increasing urinary frequency, as is the case in this patient. However, a vaginal ultrasound would most likely detect a gestation sac (unless < 4 weeks gestational age) and urine β-hCG would already be positive at this time.

E) INCORRECT:

In Couvade syndrome, it is the partner or a close friend/relative of an expecting mother who experiences mild symptoms of pregnancy (e.g., weight gain, altered hormone levels, morning nausea) without believing that they are themselves pregnant.

F) INCORRECT:

Patients with an incomplete abortion may experience symptoms of pregnancy, as seen in this patient. However, during a spontaneous abortion, patients will experience intense cramping and bleeding. Furthermore, a urine pregnancy test would be positive, the cervical os would be open with evidence of fetal tissue, and the fetus would also be visible on ultrasound.

G) INCORRECT:

Patients with an ectopic pregnancy can have symptoms of pregnancy without a gestational sac in the uterus, as is the case in this patient. However, a urine pregnancy test would be positive and the patient would have developed abdominal pain and vaginal bleeding as the fetus grew.
Image Description:

Ultrasound pelvis (transabdominal; transverse plane) of a 31-year-old woman with history of abdominal pain, presyncope, and a positive pregnancy test

A thick-walled echogenic ring lesion (blue overlay) is seen in the right adnexa, adjacent to which there is trace free fluid (yellow overlay). No uterine masses were identified and an intrauterine gestation was not detected. The adnexal lesion proved to represent a gestational sac of an ectopic pregnancy.

An adnexal mass separate from the ovary is a common presentation of ectopic pregnancy. The diagnosis becomes more specific if a yolk sac or living embryo is detected within the mass. Color Doppler of an ectopic pregnancy may show prominent peripheral vascularity (ring of fire sign), which can similarly occur with a corpus luteum cyst.

Green overlay: uterine wall
Red overlay: endometrial stripe
IIA: internal iliac artery
IIV: internal illiac vein
O: ovary
questions.hint: Urine β-hCG tests have > 99% sensitivity from 14 days after the egg is implanted.

questions.text: A 25-year-old woman comes to the physician for the evaluation of blindness in her right eye that suddenly started 1 hour ago. She has no feeling of pain, pressure, or sensation of a foreign body in the right eye. She has a history of major depressive disorder treated with fluoxetine. The patient attends college and states that she has had a lot of stress lately due to relationship problems with her partner. She does not smoke or drink alcohol. She does not use illicit drugs. Her vital signs are within normal limits. Ophthalmologic examination shows a normal-appearing eye with no redness. Slit-lamp examination and fundoscopy show no abnormalities. A visual field test shows nonspecific visual field defects. An MRI of the brain shows no abnormalities. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Malingering involves the falsification of manifestations of illness to attain a secondary gain such as financial compensation or time off from work. Though this patient has a normal ophthalmologic examination and MRI, there is no indication that she is intentionally falsifying her symptom of blindness or seeking secondary gain. In addition, patients who malinger typically avoid extensive diagnostic procedures.

B) INCORRECT:

Factitious disorder is a condition in which patients intentionally falsify manifestations of illness to assume the role of a sick patient (primary gain). Though this patient has a normal ophthalmologic examination and MRI, there is no indication that she is intentionally falsifying her symptom of blindness or seeking primary gain. Patients usually also have a history of multiple health care visits, are evasive in providing history, and often refuse access to prior medical records.

C) INCORRECT:

Central retinal artery occlusion can cause sudden, painless, monocular vision loss. However, this patient does not have characteristic findings of this condition on fundoscopy such as a pale, edematous retina, and a cherry-red spot near the fovea. In addition, she does not have risk factors for central retinal artery occlusion such as age > 60 years, atrial fibrillation, carotid artery atherosclerosis, or a history of stroke.
Image Description:

Left: lateral view of the right eye in longitudinal (sagittal) section. Depiction of an embolism in the central retinal artery causing retinal ischemia.

Right: fundus photography of the right eye. Diffuse retinal ischemia causes edema in the inner retinal layers, manifesting as a gray-white discoloration of the retina (most markedly around the fovea; dotted circle). The fovea centralis, where the inner retinal layers are moved to the side, is not affected by edema. The underlying, well-vascularized choroid shines through, appearing as a cherry-red spot.

D) INCORRECT:

Retinal detachment can cause sudden, painless, monocular vision loss. However, this patient does not have other typical manifestations of this condition such as prodromal symptoms (e.g., floaters, flashes of light), an afferent pupillary defect, or a fundoscopic examination that shows a retinal tear and a detached, gray, and freely floating retina that moves with eye movements.

E) INCORRECT:

Acute stress disorder is a condition that develops after a traumatic event and manifests with symptoms such as anxiety, intrusive thoughts, and negative mood that last between 3 days and 1 month. This condition does not cause somatic manifestations (e.g., blindness).

F) INCORRECT:

Somatic symptom disorder is a condition in which a patient has persistent somatic symptoms (e.g., headache, fatigue) that result in excessive thoughts and/or behaviors that disrupt daily life. This patient has monocular blindness. However, a diagnosis of somatic symptom disorder requires symptoms to persist for ≥ 6 months.

G) INCORRECT:

Optic neuritis can cause sudden, monocular vision loss. However, this patient does not have other typical manifestations of this condition such as periocular pain, an afferent pupillary defect, or a fundoscopic examination that shows hyperemia and swelling of the optic disc. In addition, optic neuritis typically causes optic nerve inflammation that is visible on MRI.

H) CORRECT:

This patient has functional neurological symptom disorder (FND), a condition that manifests with neurologic symptoms that are inconsistent with neurologic disease. She presents with unilateral blindness but has an ophthalmologic examination and MRI that do not indicate an underlying neurologic etiology. FND is more common among young women who have a comorbid psychiatric condition and typically develops after an acute stressor (e.g., trauma, interpersonal conflict). The diagnosis of this condition requires thorough evaluation and ruling out of other possible diagnoses, such as retinal detachment in this patient with sudden, painless, monocular vision loss.

Patients with FND were classically considered to have la belle indifference, which refers to a lack of concern about their symptoms. However, la belle indifference is not specific to this condition; patients typically have distress and/or impairment.
questions.hint: This patient presents with unilateral blindness but has a normal ophthalmologic examination and MRI.

questions.text: A 28-year-old woman comes to the physician because of a 1-year history of chronic abdominal pain that developed after starting a job at a law firm. She also has abdominal bloating and constipation that started 2 weeks ago. She has had no pain with defecation or change in stool form or appearance. She is upset because she has seen two other physicians who performed tests but were unable to make a diagnosis. The patient is currently on sick leave but would like to return to work as soon as possible. She often worries about having a gastric ulcer that may perforate and insists on getting an endoscopy. She does not smoke or drink alcohol. She reports that she is under significant pressure from her managers because of frequent performance evaluations. She has a history of childhood asthma. She takes multivitamins and glucosamine daily to prevent arthritis. Her vital signs are within normal limits. The abdomen is mildly distended and slightly tender. The remainder of the examination, including a neurologic examination, shows no abnormalities. Laboratory studies are within the reference ranges. Fecal occult blood test and urea breath test are negative. Which of the following is the most likely explanation for this patient's symptoms?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Individuals with adjustment disorder present with a maladaptive emotional and/or behavioral response within 3 months of a stressful event (e.g., cancer diagnosis). Common features include excessive distress and impaired social functioning. Although this patient's symptoms began after starting a new job, her physical findings (e.g., abdominal distention) make adjustment disorder unlikely.

B) INCORRECT:

Illness anxiety disorder is diagnosed in individuals with a persistent fear of having or developing an illness in the absence of physical symptoms. Patients may also show maladaptive behavior, such as frequently changing physicians, making it an important differential diagnosis in this patient. Although she spends considerable time worrying about her health, her anxiety is caused by distinct physical symptoms, which are not expected in illness anxiety disorder.

C) INCORRECT:

Patients with malingering typically present with vague symptoms and may insist on undergoing extensive medical evaluation. Symptoms in malingering are intentionally fabricated or exaggerated for secondary gain (e.g., in order to get time off from work). There is no evidence that this patient's symptoms are feigned or exaggerated, and she wants to return to work, making another diagnosis more likely.

D) INCORRECT:

Individuals with irritable bowel syndrome (IBS) present with recurrent, nonspecific changes in bowel movements and abdominal symptoms (e.g., diffuse pain, pressure). Diagnostic criteria for IBS consist of abdominal pain on at least 1 day each week during the previous 3 months that is accompanied by at least 2 of the following features: pain with defecation, change in stool frequency, or change in stool form or appearance. Although this patient has had abdominal pain for a year and also reports new-onset constipation, which may manifest with changes in stool frequency and form, constipation has only been present for 2 weeks, meaning that the diagnostic criteria for IBS are not currently fulfilled.

E) INCORRECT:

Individuals with functional neurological disorder present with a range of neurological symptoms (e.g., altered sensory function, paralysis with no anatomical pattern) that cause significant psychosocial impairment and that cannot be attributed to a neurological condition. Unlike this patient, individuals with functional neurological symptom disorder are not preoccupied with their health. In addition, this patient does not report any neurological symptoms.

F) CORRECT:

Somatic symptom disorder manifests with one or more physical symptoms that cause significant distress and/or interfere with daily functioning, typically lasting > 6 months. The diagnostic criteria include at least one of the following: disproportionate thoughts, feelings, and/or behaviors concerning one's health, excessive anxiety about illness, and inordinate time or resources spent on health concerns. Incidence of somatic symptom disorder is higher in women and in those with a history of chronic childhood illness (e.g., asthma). After ruling out any treatable medical conditions, management consists of reducing unnecessary tests and procedures by scheduling regular appointments and establishing a therapeutic alliance with a single primary care physician. Psychotherapy (e.g., cognitive behavioral therapy) may be helpful to treat any underlying psychological causes (e.g., stress) and comorbid psychiatric conditions.

G) INCORRECT:

Individuals with factitious disorder typically have a history of seeking care from multiple providers and significant exposure to a healthcare environment (e.g., because of childhood illness) and are willing to undergo invasive treatments. Factitious disorder is characterized by the intentional falsification of an illness and/or its symptoms (e.g., factitious hypoglycemia due to surreptitious insulin use) in order to assume the sick role. There is no evidence of deceptive or attention-seeking behavior by this patient, and her symptoms appear to be genuine.
questions.hint: Individuals with this condition typically have a history of visiting multiple physicians.

questions.text: A 37-year-old man comes to the emergency department with his wife because of a 3-day history of severe pain in his right arm. He also reports that he cannot move his right arm. The symptoms began after the patient woke up one morning, having slept on his side. He is otherwise healthy. He works as a waiter and says that he feels exhausted from working several night shifts per week. He adds that he “can barely keep his eyes open” when looking after their daughter the next day. Since the onset of the pain, he has been unable to work and is fully dependent on his wife, who took on an extra shift to make enough money to pay their monthly bills. The patient appears relaxed but only allows himself to be examined after his wife convinces him. His vital signs are within normal limits. Examination shows 1/5 muscle strength in the right arm. Reflexes are normal. He has no sensation to light touch over the entire right arm and forearm. When a pinprick test is conducted, the patient rapidly withdraws the right arm. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Brachial neuritis can cause severe, unilateral shoulder pain, weakness, and sensory loss. In brachial neuritis, however, shoulder pain and neurological deficits do not occur simultaneously; neurological deficits only occur as the pain begins to subside. Moreover, this patient does not have a true neurological deficit because the deep tendon reflexes, pain sensation, and withdrawal reflex are intact.

B) INCORRECT:

Individuals with factitious disorder often report symptoms that are inconsistent with examination findings. However, patients with factitious disorder intentionally feign the symptoms of an illness, the motive for which is the emotional support or sympathy obtained by playing the “sick role” and not an external benefit (e.g., time off from work, financial compensation). Moreover, patients with a factitious disorder are usually cooperative during physical examination.

C) INCORRECT:

Individuals with somatic symptom disorder report somatic symptoms (e.g., shoulder pain, weakness) that cause excessive distress for a period of ≥ 6 months. There is usually a history of frequent visits to physicians, hospitalization, and extensive diagnostic tests. Patients with somatic symptom disorder are also distressed by the fact that they do not obtain relief from symptoms. This patient has only had symptoms for the past three days and is very possibly motivated by an external reward, neither of which is consistent with somatic symptom disorder.

D) CORRECT:

Arm weakness with decreased sensation to light touch on the arm and forearm but intact pain sensation, deep tendon reflexes, and withdrawal reflex is not consistent with any known neurological disorder. In malingering, patients intentionally feign symptoms of a physical or psychiatric illness to obtain an external benefit (e.g., time off from work, financial compensation, avoiding jail). These individuals are also typically uncooperative during physical examination. Malingering is not a mental disorder.

Patients with malingering should be approached in a nonthreatening, calm, distant yet empathetic manner to improve the physician-patient relationship and give the patient the opportunity to be honest without becoming uncomfortable and possibly compromising this relationship.

E) INCORRECT:

Individuals with functional neurological symptom disorder experience neurological symptoms that are not consistent with any known neurologic disorder (e.g., arm weakness with decreased light touch sensation in the arm and forearm but intact pain sensation, deep tendon reflexes, and withdrawal reflex) and may be calm when describing their symptoms. However, there is no external motive for feigning symptoms and individuals usually have a history of an underlying depressive or anxiety disorder. Functional neurological symptom disorder is also more common among women than men and typically occurs during adolescence or early childhood.

F) INCORRECT:

Radial nerve palsy may occur as a result of nerve compression. Compression of the radial nerve only impairs forearm supination, forearm, wrist, and finger extension, and sensory perception on the dorsal surface of the upper limb. Severe shoulder pain, weakness of both flexors and extensors in the arm, and sensory loss on the dorsal and ventral surfaces of both the arm and forearm are not consistent with radial nerve palsy. Moreover, this patient does not have a true neurological deficit because deep tendon reflexes, sensitivity to pain, and the withdrawal reflex are intact.

G) INCORRECT:

Illness anxiety disorder is diagnosed in individuals with a persistent fear (lasting ≥ 6 months) of having or developing an illness despite having no or only mild physical symptoms. This patient reports severe symptoms that started only three days ago and he is very possibly motivated by an external reward, neither of which is consistent with illness anxiety disorder.
questions.hint: This patient reports paralysis and pain in his right arm, but clinical findings are inconsistent with his statements and indicate that movement is preserved. The fact that he is reluctant to undergo examination should raise concern that an external reward is at stake (e.g., time off from work and potentially obtaining insurance money).

questions.text: A 52-year-old woman comes to the physician because of mild fatigue and dizziness for the past 2 days. She has not been to work since yesterday due to her symptoms. She says she has "very high blood sugar” and has had similar episodes often in the past 2 years, for which she has visited multiple doctors around the city. She has also purchased a home glucose monitoring device, which she uses daily. Since the symptoms began, she has become socially withdrawn and spends much of her time at home researching diabetes on the internet. One week ago, she took a day off work because of her symptoms. She is not on any treatment. She has had three laboratory test reports that all show normal fasting and post-meal blood glucose levels. Her father and brother have type 2 diabetes mellitus. She appears anxious. Vital signs are normal. Physical examination shows no abnormalities. Random serum glucose is 128 mg/dL. Which of the following is the most likely explanation for this patient's symptoms?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Patients with somatic symptom disorder have symptoms that cause significant distress and they often undergo extensive testing without a diagnosis being found. However, patients with somatic symptom disorder tend to have physical symptoms (e.g., heartburn, headache, abdominal pain) which must be present for at least 6 months to meet diagnostic criteria (according to the DSM-5). This patient is preoccupied with having diabetes, which is likely the result of her symptoms.

B) INCORRECT:

Patients with factitious disorder can exhibit a preoccupation with having an illness. However, these patients will intentionally falsify their disease (e.g., inject insulin to induce hypoglycemia) to assume the role of a sick person. This patient has consistently normal test results without evidence of falsified disease.

C) INCORRECT:

Malingering patients may present with vague complaints (e.g., dizziness, fatigue) that cannot be verified by medical testing (e.g., normal fasting blood glucose levels). Malingering patients intentionally feign their symptoms to achieve some external gain, such as this patient possibly taking sick leave to avoid work. However, malingering symptoms are usually not specific to a certain medical diagnosis. Additionally, they are not preoccupied with excessive health-related behaviors (e.g., daily use of a glucometer, extensive internet research, numerous doctor's visits) over such a long period of time. This constellation of features is more consistent with another diagnosis.

D) INCORRECT:

Patients can experience health-related anxiety as a response to a serious medical condition being revealed as a possibility (e.g., the potential of developing diabetes with a strong family history). However, the anxiety should be proportionate to the seriousness of the medical condition and should resolve over 2–3 months.

E) INCORRECT:

Although this patient may have intrusive thoughts about having diabetes (i.e., obsessions) with associated compulsive behaviors (e.g., checking the internet, seeking reassurance from physicians), she lacks the stereotyped, repetitive behaviors that tend to characterize obsessive-compulsive disorder (e.g., repeatedly checking the door is locked). Furthermore, there is no evidence that her obsessions extend beyond fears of having an illness, which suggests another diagnosis.

F) INCORRECT:

Patients with unipolar major depression can obsess over their physical health, as seen in this patient. However, this patient does not display a depressed mood or anhedonia, which is required for diagnosis of major depressive disorder.

G) CORRECT:

This patient exhibits a persistent preoccupation with having diabetes for ≥ 6 months, despite no clinical evidence to support this diagnosis. She exhibits excessive health-related behaviors (e.g., daily use of a glucometer, extensive internet research, numerous doctor's visits) and has only mild somatic symptoms (e.g., fatigue). Based on these findings, she most likely has illness anxiety disorder (previously referred to as hypochondriasis). Treatment for illness anxiety disorder includes regular scheduled primary care physician visits to address patient concerns and cognitive behavioral therapy. Comorbid psychiatric diseases should also be treated if present.

H) INCORRECT:

This patient's family history puts her at risk for type 2 diabetes mellitus, and the early stages of this disease can manifest with normal random blood sugar, as seen in this patient. However, there should be evidence of at least one abnormal blood glucose level in the past 2 years of testing. Furthermore, this patient's intense preoccupation with having diabetes suggests another diagnosis. A single random blood glucose measurement of ≥ 200 mg/dL would establish the diagnosis of diabetes mellitus.
questions.hint: This patient is preoccupied with having diabetes and has visited multiple doctors over the past 2 years for this condition.

questions.text: A 20-year-old woman comes to the emergency department for right arm and leg weakness, numbness, and tingling that has been resolving gradually. The symptoms started 4 hours ago, after she had an argument with her boyfriend. She says she has been limping and cannot use her right arm anymore. She has never had similar symptoms in the past. She has a history of genital herpes and trichotillomania. She is alert and oriented. Physical examination shows upper and lower face symmetry and normal speech. She has 5/5 strength in all extremities and 5/5 right ankle plantar flexion when lying down. She has 4/5 strength in the right arm and leg when ambulating. She cannot stand on her toes when asked. Her deep tendon reflexes are 2+ bilaterally. She has normal proprioception, light touch sensation, and two-point discrimination in all extremities. She has a negative Spurling test. CT of the head without contrast shows no abnormalities. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Cognitive behavioral therapy (CBT) is an effective long-term treatment for FNSD. Strategies for treating FNSD with CBT include establishing a shared understanding of the diagnosis, identifying treatment goals, challenging maladaptive behaviors and thoughts (e.g., thinking of functional impairment as permanent), and realistically anticipating setbacks in the treatment course. However, this patient has new-onset FNSD, and another step in management is more appropriate at this time.

B) INCORRECT:

Patients with FNSD that does not improve with conservative therapies may benefit from antidepressants like citalopram, which can treat both FNSD and common comorbidities such as generalized anxiety disorder and major depressive disorder. However, antidepressants are not the recommended first-line treatment for FNSD.

C) INCORRECT:

Alteplase (tPA) is appropriate for treating stroke. Although this patient's symptoms began 4 hours ago, which is within the therapeutic window for thrombolysis (i.e., within 4.5 hours of symptom onset), she has an inconsistent neurological exam, and CT of the head was negative for acute intracranial abnormalities, making a cerebrovascular condition unlikely.

D) CORRECT:

Patient education is the initial step in management of FNSD, as symptoms may resolve after an explanation of the condition and its causes. Strategies for patient education include asking about their perspective of the problem, taking their symptoms seriously, explaining clinical features that are inconsistent with neurological disease, and emphasizing that symptoms are often reversible. Cognitive behavioral therapy can further help patients to understand and manage their symptoms. Pharmacotherapy (e.g., antidepressants, anxiolytics, or mood stabilizers) can be considered for patients with a comorbid psychiatric disorder.

E) INCORRECT:

Physical therapy may be useful as an adjunctive treatment for patients with motor symptoms of FNSD, but it is not the most appropriate initial step in management of new-onset FNSD. Strategies for treating FNSD with physical therapy include encouraging normal functional movement (e.g., transfers and walking) and teaching patients to suppress abnormal movements or deficits (e.g., using distraction techniques).

F) INCORRECT:

Patients who do not respond to other conservative treatment approaches for FNSD may benefit from biofeedback, especially individuals with functional tremors. In this patient, another management approach should be tried first.
questions.hint: This young female patient has a history of psychiatric illness (trichotillomania) and presents with isolated neurological symptoms following an emotional stressor. Imaging shows no abnormalities, and focal neurological findings are inconsistent, which is highly characteristic of functional neurological symptom disorder (FNSD).

questions.text:
A 26-year-old nurse comes to the physician because of a 2-month history of fatigue. She says, "I am concerned that I may have cancer but I do not want to undergo any major investigations." She was diagnosed with peptic ulcer disease 6 months ago. Her only medication is omeprazole. Menses occur at regular 28-day intervals with normal flow. She is not sexually active. She lives alone. She states that she enjoys her work as a nurse and has not taken time off from work despite not feeling well. She appears tired and pale but is not in acute distress. She is wearing long-sleeved clothing. Her temperature is 36.5°C (97.7°F), pulse is 109/min, and blood pressure is 110/75 mm Hg. Physical examination shows pale conjunctivae. A grade 2/6 systolic ejection murmur is heard along the right upper sternal border. There are numerous scabs along the course of her left arm veins. The remainder of the examination shows no abnormalities. Laboratory studies show:


Hemoglobin
7.5 g/dL


Mean corpuscular volume
89 μm3


Leukocyte count
10,000/mm3 with a normal differential


Platelet count
180,000/mm3



Reticulocyte count
13.3%


Erythrocyte sedimentation rate
16 mm/h


Serum



 Na+

139 mEq/L


 K+

3.9 mEq/L


 Ca2+

8.5 mg/dL


 Creatinine
0.8 mg/dL


 Bilirubin, total
0.05 mg/dL


 AST
31 U/L


 ALT
20 U/L


 Lactate dehydrogenase

110 U/L


Test of the stool for occult blood is negative. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Patients with factitious disorder intentionally falsify symptoms in the absence of external rewards (e.g., financial gain, time off from work, medications) to assume a patient role. This patient's acute blood loss in the setting of numerous brown scabs along her arm veins is suggestive of anemia due to chronic blood loss from self-induced phlebotomy. This patient's pallor, fatigue, tachycardia, and systolic ejection murmur of hyperdynamic circulation are likely secondary to anemia. Factitious disorder is more prevalent among women and healthcare workers.

B) INCORRECT:

Infective endocarditis (IE) can cause fatigue, a heart murmur, and anemia, and evidence of repeated venous access might raise concern for intravenous drug use (IVDU), which is a risk factor for IE. However, the absence of other features of IE (e.g., fever, arthralgia, peripheral embolic and immunologic phenomena, acute kidney injury, increased ESR) makes this diagnosis unlikely. Moreover, patients with IVDU develop right-sided IE with murmurs at the tricuspid or pulmonary locations, unlike the murmur at the aortic location in this patient.

C) INCORRECT:

Patients with somatic symptom disorder (SSD) have symptoms that cause significant distress or impairment and have treatment-seeking behavior in the absence of an external reward (e.g., sick leave, financial gain). However, patients with SSD have real perceived symptoms and do not falsify symptoms. This patient's blood loss in the setting of numerous scabs along her arm veins raises suspicion for anemia from self-induced phlebotomy.

D) INCORRECT:

A congenital bicuspid aortic valve would cause early-onset aortic stenosis and can manifest with a systolic murmur at the aortic area and macroangiopathic hemolytic anemia. This patient, however, lacks findings suggestive of hemolysis (e.g., hyperbilirubinemia, increased LDH). The patient's murmur is likely due to hyperdynamic circulation and her anemia is most likely the result of blood loss.

E) INCORRECT:

Patients with functional neurological symptom disorder present with neurological symptoms (e.g., altered motor or sensory function) that cause significant distress or psychosocial impairment and cannot be fully explained by a neurological condition. This patient does not have any significant neurological symptoms and presents with anemia, making this diagnosis unlikely.

F) INCORRECT:

Patients with iron deficiency anemia typically have a low MCV (microcytic anemia), and the reticulocyte count would be low or normal because there is no reactive increase in erythropoiesis since iron levels are inadequate for hemoglobin synthesis.

G) INCORRECT:

Patients who are malingering intentionally falsify symptoms. This patient's acute blood loss in the setting of numerous brown crusts along her arm veins is suggestive of anemia from self-induced phlebotomy. However, the goal of malingering is the attainment of an external reward (e.g., medications, financial compensation, time off from work, avoiding going to prison). This patient is seeking care without any indication that she seeks other types of external reward, meaning another diagnosis is more likely.
questions.hint: Normocytic anemia, a highly elevated reticulocyte count, and no evidence of hemolysis indicate anemia due to blood loss. The numerous scabs along her arm veins are consistent with repeated venous access.

questions.text:
A 45-year-old woman comes to the emergency department with recurrent episodes of shaking, sweating, and palpitations. The patient is confused and complains of hunger. One week ago, she had similar symptoms that improved after eating. She has hypertension and a history of biliary pancreatitis. She underwent cholecystectomy 1 year ago. She works as a nurse aide in a nursing care facility. She does not smoke or drink alcohol. She does not exercise. Her temperature is 36.7°C (98°F), pulse is 104/min, respirations are 20/min, and blood pressure is 135/88 mm Hg. Examination shows tremors and diaphoresis. Laboratory studies show:


Blood glucose
50 mg/dL


Thyroid-stimulating hormone
1 mU/L



C-peptide (fasting)

0.5 ng/mL (N = 0.8–1.9)


Abdominal ultrasound reveals a 1-cm anechoic lesion in the head of the pancreas. Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient's symptoms?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Patients who malinger present with feigned or exaggerated symptoms that are usually not specific to a known medical condition. The aim of malingering is to attain a secondary gain (e.g., compensation, time off from work). Patients are typically uncooperative and insist on undergoing an extensive medical evaluation. This patient has clear clinical signs and laboratory evidence that are consistent with hypoglycemia, and there is no indication that she is seeking a secondary gain.

B) INCORRECT:

This patient likely has a pancreatic pseudocyst, given the anechoic lesions seen on abdominal ultrasound and recent biliary pancreatitis. However, a pancreatic pseudocyst would not cause hypoglycemia. Instead, patients tend to have abdominal pain, vascular occlusion, or duodenal or biliary obstruction.

C) INCORRECT:

A pancreatic neoplasm, such as an insulinoma, could cause periodic hypoglycemia and high levels of insulin. However, in hyperinsulinism due to pancreatic neoplasm, C-peptide levels would also be high. This patient's low C-peptide suggests another diagnosis.

D) INCORRECT:

Hyperthyroidism due to Graves disease can cause tremors, diaphoresis, and palpitations, as seen in this patient. However, this patient's TSH is normal, making hyperthyroidism unlikely. Furthermore, she does not have physical signs of Graves disease, such as exophthalmos, pretibial myxedema, and diffuse goiter.

E) INCORRECT:

Patients with type 1 diabetes mellitus have low C-peptide levels due to low endogenous insulin production. However, low insulin in patients with untreated type 1 diabetes mellitus is caused by pancreatic beta-cell dysfunction, which results in hyperglycemia rather than hypoglycemia. Moreover, it would be very unusual for a 45-year-old woman to present with new-onset type 1 diabetes mellitus. Patients with type 1 diabetes mellitus can have hypoglycemia with low C-peptide from an excess of exogenous insulin. However, type 1 diabetes in itself does not cause hypoglycemia.

F) INCORRECT:

Reactive postprandial hypoglycemia can manifest as symptomatic hypoglycemia with high levels of insulin, as seen in this patient. However, since the insulin is endogenous in reactive postprandial hypoglycemia, C-peptide levels would also be high. This patient's low C-peptide level suggests another diagnosis.

G) CORRECT:

This patient has hypoglycemia (blood glucose < 70 mg/dL) with neuroglycopenic (e.g., confusion, drowsiness, dizziness, blurry vision) and adrenergic symptoms (e.g., diaphoresis, hunger, tingling, tremor, palpitations). Because her C-peptide level is low, she likely has factitious hypoglycemia resulting from surreptitious exogenous insulin use. This behavior is often caused by factitious disorder, a psychiatric condition in which an individual feigns signs of a medical condition in order to assume the role of a sick patient. The diagnostic criteria for factitious disorder are the intentional falsification of an illness, presenting oneself as ill, and deception in spite of any evident reward, in the absence of another condition that would better explain these behaviors. This patient has access to insulin as a nurse aide and is injecting insulin to assume the sick role.
questions.hint: This patient's low C-peptide indicates that she has low levels of endogenous insulin.

questions.text: A 32-year-old woman is brought to the emergency department by her neighbors 30 minutes after they found her unconscious in her yard. Her neighbors report that she has been spending more time at home by herself because she recently lost her job. On arrival, she is unable to provide a history. Her pulse is 76/min, respirations are 13/min, and blood pressure is 114/72 mm Hg. Examination shows significant weakness of the left upper and lower extremities. She is unable to plantarflex the ankle while supine. She is able to stand on her toes. Her gait is unsteady. Deep tendon reflexes are 3+ and symmetric. A CT scan of the head shows no abnormalities. An MRI of the brain and MR angiography show no abnormalities. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

This patient has functional neurological symptom disorder (FND), a condition that manifests with neurologic symptoms that are inconsistent with neurologic disease. A characteristic finding in patients with FND is a neurologic deficit that manifests inconsistently during an examination, such as this patient's transient inability to plantarflex the ankles. This condition is more common among young women and typically develops after an acute stressor (e.g., trauma, interpersonal conflict). The diagnosis of FND requires thorough evaluation and ruling out of other possible diagnoses, such as a cerebrovascular accident in this patient with unilateral weakness and an unsteady gait after a loss of consciousness.

Other manifestations of FND include seizures, movement and speech disorders, sensory disturbances, and visual impairment.

B) INCORRECT:

Factitious disorder is a condition in which patients intentionally falsify manifestations of illness to assume the role of a sick patient (primary gain). Symptoms often manifest inconsistently during an examination (e.g., transient inability to plantarflex the toes). However, there is no indication that this patient is intentionally falsifying her symptoms or seeking primary gain. Patients usually also have a history of multiple health care visits, are evasive in providing history, and often refuse access to prior medical records.

C) INCORRECT:

Malingering involves the falsification of manifestations of illness to attain a secondary gain such as financial compensation or time off from work. Symptoms often manifest inconsistently during an examination (e.g., transient inability to plantarflex the toes). However, there is no indication that this patient is intentionally falsifying her symptoms or seeking a secondary gain. In addition, patients who malinger typically avoid extensive diagnostic procedures.

D) INCORRECT:

Somatic symptom disorder is a condition in which a patient has persistent somatic symptoms (e.g., headache, fatigue) that result in excessive thoughts and/or behaviors that disrupt daily life. This patient appears anxious and has weakness and an unsteady gait. However, a diagnosis of somatic symptom disorder requires symptoms to persist for ≥ 6 months.

E) INCORRECT:

Acute stress disorder is a condition that develops after a traumatic event and manifests with symptoms such as anxiety, intrusive thoughts, and negative mood that last between 3 days and 1 month. This condition does not cause somatic manifestations (e.g., weakness, unsteady gait).

F) INCORRECT:

Acute hemorrhagic stroke can cause unilateral weakness and an unsteady gait after a loss of consciousness. However, this condition manifests with abnormalities on neuroimaging (e.g., hyperdense lesions on CT scan), which are not seen in this patient.
questions.hint: This patient presents with a neurologic deficit that manifests inconsistently; she is unable to plantarflex the ankle while supine but can stand on her toes.

questions.text: A 42-year-old man comes to the physician because of a 3-year history of urinating up to 20 times each day. He has not had any dysuria and nocturia. He has been evaluated by several urologists but has not received a specific diagnosis despite extensive diagnostic testing. Various pharmacologic treatments have not improved his symptoms. He quit his job 1 year ago and stopped attending social events because his frequent urination has been disruptive. He spends most of his time at the library trying to learn what could be causing his symptoms. He would like to undergo a CT scan of his entire body to evaluate for cancer. Physical examination and laboratory studies show no abnormalities. Mental status examination shows a depressed mood and constricted affect. There is no evidence of suicidal ideation. Which of the following is the most likely explanation for this patient's symptoms?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Illness anxiety disorder manifests with excessive health-related behaviors (e.g., frequent evaluation and extensive diagnostic testing) and preoccupation related to illness despite having no physical symptoms. This patient's frequent urination is a significant physical symptom.

B) INCORRECT:

Malingering is characterized by feigned symptoms or false claims of having an illness to obtain secondary gain (e.g., time off from work). Patients often present with vague complaints that do not conform to a known medical condition and insist on extensive medical evaluation. Though this patient requests additional testing, there is no clear attempt to obtain secondary gain in this case.

C) INCORRECT:

Atypical depression is diagnosed in individuals with depression, mood reactivity, and physical complaints without an identifiable somatic cause. An increased need for sleep and leaden paralysis are the characteristic features, but patients may also present with pain and generalized discomfort, none of which is seen in this patient. While his mental status examination showed a depressed mood and constricted affect, the abnormal preoccupation with his health is more suggestive of a different diagnosis.

D) CORRECT:

This patient has somatic symptom disorder, a condition characterized by ≥ 6 months of excessive thoughts, feelings, and/or behaviors related to a somatic symptom (e.g., heartburn, fatigue, headache, pain). His previous diagnostic workup did not reveal any known medical etiology of his frequent urination. Patients with this condition typically show a preoccupation with their health and develop significant distress, anxiety, and fear of severe illness.

E) INCORRECT:

Adjustment disorder manifests with a maladaptive emotional and/or behavior response that causes distress and impaired functioning within 3 months after the onset of a stressor. Though this patient experiences significant distress and impaired social functioning, he does not have a history of a specific stressful event.

F) INCORRECT:

Urinary tract infections can manifest with frequent urination but typically also cause other symptoms such as dysuria, urgency, and suprapubic pain. In addition, urinalysis of men with urinary tract infections almost always shows pyuria, but this man's laboratory evaluation showed no abnormalities.
questions.hint: This man's frequent urination has caused him significant distress, and he spends a significant amount of time attending to his health concerns. Patients with this man's condition typically have a history of extensive diagnostic testing.

questions.text: A 38-year-old woman comes to the physician for the first time because of a 2-year history of lower back pain and fatigue. She also says that she occasionally feels out of breath. Her symptoms are not associated with physical activity. She has seen multiple physicians over the past year. Extensive workup including blood and urine tests, abdominal ultrasound, MRI of the back, and cardiac stress testing has shown no abnormalities. The patient asks for a medication to alleviate her symptoms. Which of the following is the most appropriate response by the physician?

choices.text: "I would like to investigate your shortness of breath by performing coronary artery catheterization."
"Your symptoms are suggestive of a condition called somatic symptom disorder."
"We should start you on a pain management regimen with tramadol to address your chronic back pain."
"I would like to assess your symptoms causing you the most distress and schedule monthly follow-up appointments."
"I would like to refer you to a psychiatric specialist to start behavioral psychotherapy."
"Your desire for pain medication is suggestive of a medication dependence disorder."

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Cardiac catheterization is an invasive procedure that carries a risk for complications. This patient has had a prior cardiac stress test with no abnormalities, making her pretest probability for coronary artery disease low. Cardiac catheterization would not be indicated here. In general, further testing should be limited in patients with somatic symptom disorder who have already undergone extensive workup.

B) INCORRECT:

Discussing a psychiatric diagnosis with the patient is important as she has a right to be fully informed of her condition. However, the diagnosis of somatic symptom disorder should be delivered in the context of a strong physician-patient relationship, whereas this statement is blunt and might alienate the patient. Another statement would be more appropriate at this point.

C) INCORRECT:

Tramadol is a narcotic pain medication that carries a significant risk of dependency when prescribed for the treatment of chronic pain. This patient has undergone extensive work-up revealing no underlying organic origin for her pain. Narcotic pain medication is unlikely to resolve her symptoms.

D) CORRECT:

Regularly scheduled office visits with the same physician are recognized as the most effective treatment for somatic symptom disorder. Psychotherapy (e.g., cognitive behavioral therapy) is an additional component of first-line treatment. This patient has already had a comprehensive medical workup, suggesting that an organic cause of her symptoms is very unlikely and that further diagnostic steps would not be appropriate.

E) INCORRECT:

Referral to a psychiatrist is often indicated in cases of somatic symptom disorder. However, this should be recommended in the context of an established and strong physician-patient relationship. This patient presents to establish care after previously seeing several physicians. It would be most prudent to build rapport prior to discussing referral to a psychiatrist.

F) INCORRECT:

Criticizing the patient's request for medications can be perceived as accusatory and counterproductive to the physician-patient relationship. Patients with somatic symptom disorder, as this patient's presentation suggests, experience real symptoms that may prompt them to seek treatment. Empathetic listening and legitimization of the patient's concern are important, as is providing education regarding the reasons for not prescribing medications.
questions.hint: Chronic symptoms that do not fit a specific diagnosis, visits to multiple physicians, and negative findings after an extensive workup are suggestive of somatic symptom disorder.

questions.text: A 5-year-old boy is brought to the emergency department by his mother because of a sudden loss of consciousness. He has asthma and has been hospitalized multiple times. His mother has type 2 diabetes mellitus. He is somnolent and diaphoretic. Serum studies show a glucose concentration of 22 mg/dL and a potassium concentration of 2.4 mEq/L. A dextrose infusion is administered, after which his glucose concentration normalizes and his symptoms improve. He is admitted to the hospital for further observation. Overnight, he has another episode of decreased consciousness. Serum studies taken during the episode show a glucose concentration of 19 mg/dL, an insulin concentration of 108 mIU/L (N = 2.6–24.9), and a C-peptide concentration of 0.3 ng/mL (N = 0.8–3.1). Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Malingering is the intentional falsification of symptoms and/or diagnoses for secondary gain (e.g., financial incentive, time off from work). This boy has received exogenous insulin, which causes hyperinsulinemia, hypoglycemic episodes, and decreased serum C-peptide concentrations (because exogenous insulin does not contain C-peptide). However, malingering is not the most likely diagnosis in this scenario because it is very unlikely that this 5-year-old boy has the capability or motivation to seek secondary gain.

B) INCORRECT:

A glucagonoma is a pancreatic neuroendocrine tumor that produces excess glucagon, which results in hyperglycemia (not hypoglycemia). In addition, this patient does not have other typical manifestations of a glucagonoma, which include necrolytic migratory erythema, venous thromboembolic conditions, weight loss, and neuropsychiatric changes (e.g., depression, psychosis). Moreover, this tumor is rare and typically develops in adulthood.

C) INCORRECT:

Primary adrenal insufficiency can cause hypoglycemic episodes as a result of decreased glucose production due to glucocorticoid deficiency. However, this patient does not have other manifestations of primary adrenal insufficiency, which include gastrointestinal symptoms (e.g., nausea, vomiting), fatigue, hypotension, dizziness, and skin hyperpigmentation. Moreover, primary adrenal insufficiency does not cause hyperinsulinemia or decreased serum C-peptide concentrations.

D) INCORRECT:

An insulinoma is a pancreatic neuroendocrine tumor that produces excess insulin, which results in hyperinsulinemia and hypoglycemic episodes. However, endogenous insulin production causes increased (not decreased) serum C-peptide concentrations. Moreover, this tumor is rare and typically develops in adulthood.

E) INCORRECT:

Functional neurological symptom disorder is a somatic symptom disorder characterized by significant distress and/or psychosocial impairment caused by neurologic symptoms (e.g., paralysis, weakness, visual disturbances) that cannot be fully attributed to another condition. This patient has episodic loss of consciousness, but these symptoms are caused by his hypoglycemic episodes.

F) INCORRECT:

A somatostatinoma is a pancreatic neuroendocrine tumor that produces excess somatostatin, which results in decreased secretion of several hormones, including insulin, glucagon, and growth hormone. This patient has hyperinsulinemia, not hypoinsulinemia. In addition, this patient does not have typical manifestations of a somatostatinoma, which include abdominal pain, weight loss, and hyperglycemic episodes (not hypoglycemic episodes). Moreover, this tumor is rare and typically develops in adulthood.

G) CORRECT:

Factitious disorder imposed on another is a psychiatric condition in which an individual intentionally falsifies manifestations of disease in another individual (e.g., their child or elderly dependent) for primary gain. This boy's mother, who has type 2 diabetes mellitus, has most likely given him exogenous insulin, which causes hyperinsulinemia, hypoglycemic episodes, and decreased serum C-peptide concentrations (because exogenous insulin does not contain C-peptide). The primary gain in this scenario includes the attention, sympathy, and care given to sick patients and their families.
questions.hint: Endogenous insulin release involves the cleavage of proinsulin into insulin and C-peptide.

questions.text: An 18-year-old man is brought to the physician by his mother because of a 1-week history of vision problems. He recently enlisted in the US Army and started military training 2 weeks ago, but was not able to continue because his vision became severely blurry. He ambulates with a walking cane and wears dark glasses. He has no personal history of serious illness. His father has hyperopia. The patient appears anxious. Vital signs are within normal limits. Inspection of the eyes shows no abnormalities. Fundoscopy findings are normal. Snellen eye chart examination shows a visual acuity of 20/200 on the right and 20/100 on the left. When the physician suddenly passes a hand in front of the patient's eyes, he starts blinking. When asked to close his eyes, extend his hands, and touch the tip of his nose with his index finger, the patient touches his eyebrow and chin instead of his nose. The remainder of the neurologic examination is unremarkable. When asked to perform an additional perimetry test, the patient says “I'm really tired at this point and would really like to go home. I would really appreciate it if you could verify that I cannot see and that I cannot continue the military training.” In addition to acknowledging the patient's concerns, which of the following is the most appropriate action from the physician?

choices.text: Initiate a discussion about the patient's recent enlistment to the military
Provide the patient with an exemption letter for military service
Refer the patient to an ophthalmologist for further evaluation
Educate the patient about his diagnosis

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Meeting on a regular basis in order to build a collaborative patient-physician relationship is important for patients with somatic symptom disorder, a mental disorder in which patients experience various somatic symptoms resulting in significant distress. However, this patient's presentation suggests that he is malingering, which is not a psychiatric disorder, but rather an intentional behavior motivated by an external reward (e.g., avoiding work, obtaining insurance money). It would be inappropriate to schedule follow-up meetings without addressing his malingering behavior.

B) CORRECT:

Initiating a discussion about his recent enlistment to the military in a calm, distant, yet empathetic manner gives the patient the opportunity to be honest without becoming uncomfortable and possibly compromising the patient-physician relationship. Malingering individuals are often noncompliant and insist on undergoing extensive medical evaluation. Unnecessary referrals should be avoided because they perpetuate malingering, which is a behavior and not a psychiatric disorder.

C) INCORRECT:

Acknowledging the patient's vision loss and writing an exemption letter for military training would reward and perpetuate his malingering behavior.

D) INCORRECT:

Acknowledging the patient's vision loss and referring him to an ophthalmologist would be indicated if a medical condition of the visual pathway was suspected. No medical conditions of the visual pathway are suspected in this patient, so this action would not be appropriate.

E) INCORRECT:

Patient education is the first-line treatment for functional neurological symptom disorder, a mental disorder that can manifest with vision loss without evidence of a defective visual pathway. This patient is most likely malingering, which is not a psychiatric diagnosis but rather an intentional behavior motivated by an external reward (e.g., avoiding work, obtaining insurance money), so patient education would not be appropriate.
questions.hint: This patient's physical examination findings (abnormal finger-to-nose test indicating a cerebellar condition, eye blinking as a response to a sudden hand wave indicating intact visual pathway) do not correlate with his presenting symptom (blurry vision) and additional examination findings (poor visual acuity indicating defective visual pathway). In combination with his request for a letter excusing him from military training, this should raise concern for malingering.

questions.text:
A 47-year-old woman with a history of migraines and chronic pelvic pain presents in the emergency department (ED) with right-sided chest pain that is sharp and nonradiating. She is terrified that she is having a heart attack. Her electrocardiogram and troponin levels are within normal limits, and there were no ischemic changes noted during an exercise stress test.
Her medical records indicate that this is her fifth visit to the ED in the past month for various problems, including abdominal pain, joint pain, nausea, diarrhea, and back pain. At each of the previous visits, the medical workup was unremarkable, and the test results were explained to the patient.
The ED physician explains that her cardiac evaluation was normal. She does not have a primary care provider, so she is referred to your practice for primary care. At her initial visit, she asks to be referred to a cardiologist.
After suggesting holding off on a cardiology referral, which one of the following questions would be most appropriate to ask this patient?

choices.text: I see that you have been to the emergency department five times recently. Does this seem like a lot to you?
Do you realize that psychological difficulties often manifest with real body pain?
Can I review your test results with you so you can see how well your heart is functioning?
Would you be willing to make regularly scheduled clinic appointments with me?
Do you realize that frequent visits to an emergency department can limit our ability to care for patients who have real medical needs?

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Questions that suggest a psychiatric basis for the symptoms are typically alienating, as are challenges that suggest intentional overutilization of medical resources. Patients with somatic symptom disorder are generally not reassured by negative tests. The adverse effects of ineffective treatments and intrusive investigations can increase the patient's feelings of frustration and make his or her suffering worse. Clinicians may also become increasingly impatient and less empathic over time.

B) INCORRECT:

Questions that suggest a psychiatric basis for the symptoms are typically alienating, as are challenges that suggest intentional overutilization of medical resources. Patients with somatic symptom disorder are generally not reassured by negative tests. The adverse effects of ineffective treatments and intrusive investigations can increase the patient's feelings of frustration and make his or her suffering worse. Clinicians may also become increasingly impatient and less empathic over time.

C) INCORRECT:

Patients with somatic symptom disorder are generally not reassured by negative tests. The adverse effects of ineffective treatments and intrusive investigations can increase the patient's feelings of frustration and make his or her suffering worse. Clinicians may also become increasingly impatient and less empathic over time.

D) CORRECT:

A patient with somatic symptom disorder has somatic symptoms that are accompanied by excessive thoughts, feelings, and/or behaviors related to those symptoms, leading to distress or a decline in functioning. The suffering is authentic, but the anxiety level — and the time and energy devoted to health concerns — is out of proportion to the seriousness of the symptoms. The symptoms may or may not have a medical explanation. Thus, the absence of a medical explanation for the symptoms is not a hallmark of somatic symptom disorder.

When a patient does not require referral to a specialist but has a high degree of health-related anxiety, the clinician should provide reassurance and recommend frequent, time-limited visits with a primary care provider. The patient is not required to have symptoms in order to have regular visits with the provider.

The aim is to foster a helping relationship by establishing a regular schedule of visits.

In the context of regular primary care visits, the patient may respond well to psychoeducation, relaxation training, and pharmacologic treatment aimed at comorbid symptoms of anxiety, depression, or obsessive-compulsive disorder, provided in the primary care setting. In this illness, it is often more helpful for the primary care clinician to consult with a psychiatrist than to refer the patient to a psychiatrist directly.

Key learning point: The most effective approach for managing a patient with somatic symptom disorder is to provide reassurance and recommend frequent visits to a regular outpatient provider to address concerns.

E) INCORRECT:

Questions that suggest a psychiatric basis for the symptoms are typically alienating, as are challenges that suggest intentional overutilization of medical resources. Patients with somatic symptom disorder are generally not reassured by negative tests. The adverse effects of ineffective treatments and intrusive investigations can increase the patient's feelings of frustration and make his or her suffering worse. Clinicians may also become increasingly impatient and less empathic over time.

questions.text:
A 19-year-old female college student arrives at the campus clinic tearful and anxious. She reports ongoing chronic headaches, joint and muscle pain, and palpitations. She has also recently been concerned about worsening nausea, bloating, and diarrhea, as well as irregular menstrual bleeding. She had similar symptoms 3 years ago that resolved spontaneously.
During the past 6 weeks, she has had three visits to the emergency department and two visits to her primary care provider at home. Comprehensive medical evaluations at those visits were unremarkable.
She expresses frustration that she has suffered these symptoms for so long without anyone figuring out what is wrong with her. She reports that the symptoms have recently been so severe that her academic performance is suffering, and she is worried that she will need to leave school if the symptoms continue.
On physical examination, she has mild diffuse abdominal tenderness that seems to abate when she is engaged in conversation.
Which one of the following diagnoses is most likely in this case?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

In factitious disorder, a patient intentionally produces or feigns physical or psychological signs and symptoms of an illness. Patients with factitious disorder consciously conceal their behavior through deception. Their motivation is often obscure, but often the aim is limited to assuming the sick role.

B) CORRECT:

In somatic symptom disorder, patients have physical symptoms (including pain) that cause distress or interfere with functioning. There is a high level of anxiety associated with the symptoms, and the time and energy devoted to them is out of proportion to their seriousness. The symptoms may become so dominant in the person’s life that their health concerns override all other aspects of their personality and relationships. The absence of a medical explanation for symptoms is no longer a diagnostic criterion for somatic symptom disorder. There may or may not be an evident medical explanation for the symptoms. Patients may simultaneously have both a somatic symptom disorder and a medical illness. Recognizing the possibility of somatic symptom disorder helps the primary care clinician consider psychiatric aspects of illness during the evaluation of the patient. It may also help the patient avoid an overly aggressive or intrusive medical workup.

Key learning point: The most likely diagnosis in a young woman who has persistent physical complaints that involve multiple organ systems, that result in functional impairment, and that may or may not be fully explained by a medical condition is somatic symptom disorder.

C) INCORRECT:

In illness anxiety disorder, patients are preoccupied with the possibility of having a serious illness, but either they have no symptoms or their symptoms are mild. This patient has many somatic symptoms, so the diagnosis of somatic symptom disorder is more accurate.

D) INCORRECT:

Malingering also involves the intentional production or feigning of symptoms. Malingering is motivated, however, by some external benefit or reward (secondary gain), such as money or avoidance of work, military service, or incarceration.

E) INCORRECT:

Functional neurologic symptom disorder involves neurologic symptoms or deficits (such as blindness or memory loss) that are judged to be due to psychological factors but are not intentionally produced. The symptoms rarely, if ever, extend beyond the nervous system.

questions.text:
A 27-year-old man presents for the eighth time in the past 12 months, asking for HIV testing. He reports some fatigue and insomnia but no other physical symptoms. He also reports anxiety, which he says is related to his concerns about having HIV; he spends time every day examining his skin for evidence of Kaposi sarcoma lesions. He has been missing work because of his anxiety and is in danger of losing his job.
He has had four HIV tests during the past 18 months (all negative), has not been sexually active in the past year, and has not had any other known exposures.
Laboratory tests conducted during prior visits (including a complete blood count, comprehensive metabolic panel, and erythrocyte sedimentation rate) have been unremarkable. His vital signs are normal.
Which one of the following diagnoses is most likely in this case?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

In malingering, a patient intentionally produces physical signs and symptoms of an illness for some external benefit or reward, such as money or avoidance of work, military service, or incarceration.

B) INCORRECT:

In functional neurologic symptom disorder, a patient has one or more symptoms that affect voluntary motor or sensory function. The symptoms do not conform to a recognized neurologic or medical condition and are not better explained by another medical or mental disorder.

C) CORRECT:

Illness anxiety disorder is characterized by a pattern of maladaptive thoughts, feelings, and behaviors associated with anxiety about physical illness. It is similar to somatic symptom disorder, but in the latter, the patient’s concerns are predominantly focused on somatic symptoms rather than a specific illness. Both disorders are characterized by distress or a decline in functioning, and in both conditions, the patient’s level of anxiety — and the time and energy they devote to their health concerns — is excessive.

Most patients who would have been diagnosed with hypochondriasis in the past would now meet criteria for either somatic symptom disorder or illness anxiety disorder. The term “hypochondriasis” was eliminated in the fifth edition of the Diagnostic and Statistical Manual of Mental Disorders (DSM-5) because it is pejorative, and its use tends to undermine a therapeutic doctor-patient relationship. In addition, “absence of a medical explanation for somatic symptoms” is no longer a criterion for diagnosis of somatic symptom disorder.

Key learning point: The most likely diagnosis in a patient who is excessively preoccupied with the idea of having a serious illness without prominent physical symptoms and who does not accept reassurance about his health despite normal laboratory values is illness anxiety disorder.

D) INCORRECT:

In factitious disorder, a patient intentionally produces or feigns physical or psychological signs and symptoms of an illness. Unlike patients with the other disorders described, patients with factitious disorder consciously conceal their behavior through deception. Their motivation is often obscure, and there is no apparent external reward.

E) INCORRECT:

Generalized anxiety disorder is characterized by a high level of anxiety, but the anxiety is not focused solely on medical concerns such as illness or somatic symptoms. Instead, patients tend to exhibit excessive anxiety and worry about a variety of topics, events, or activities.

questions.text: A hospitalized 11-year-old girl with a mitochondrial disease has a 12-hour history of high fever. She was admitted to the pediatrics ward because of a 1-week history of severe vomiting. Since her admission, she has received total parenteral nutrition through a peripherally inserted central catheter (PICC) line in her left upper extremity. Yesterday, she was scheduled for PICC removal and transition to nasogastric tube feeding in preparation for discharge home. Her mother had expressed concerns that she would not tolerate the transition. She has had similar episodes of intractable vomiting in the past and underwent an inconclusive upper gastrointestinal study 6 months ago. She was also hospitalized two months ago for vomiting and received an extensive evaluation that turned out to be negative. During the last hospitalization, she had a central line placed and developed bacteremia with E. coli and Klebsiella. She appears lethargic. Her temperature is 39.0°C (102°F), pulse is 130/min, respirations are 22/min, and blood pressure is 92/52 mm Hg. Pulse oximetry on room air shows an oxygen saturation of 98%. Blood cultures are drawn from the PICC and a peripheral venipuncture, and treatment with acetaminophen, two boluses of normal saline, vancomycin, and ceftriaxone are initiated. The results of urinalysis, echocardiography, and CT scan of the chest and abdomen show no abnormalities. Three days after initiating treatment, the patient's blood pressure normalizes. Cultures from the PICC line grow Enterococcus and E. coli, and cultures from the peripheral venipuncture become positive for the same organisms 12 hours later with one-tenth the number of colony-forming units that grew in the PICC line cultures. A review of hospital records from the past month discloses that no other patients with intravascular catheters have developed bacteremia with these organisms. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?

choices.text: Consult pediatric surgery for placement of a implanted central venous port
Consult the hospital's child protection team
Consult pediatric surgery for placement of a gastrojejunostomy tube
Perform additional workup to detect an occult bowel perforation
Perform a workup for immune deficiency

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Placement of a more-permanent line would subject this patient to further unnecessary harm and increase her risk for additional bacterial infections. The goal is to remove unnecessary lines as soon as possible.

B) CORRECT:

This child has had two recent CRBSIs with bowel flora. The PICC's upper extremity location and the patient's age make it unlikely that she accidentally soiled the PICC with fecal matter. Iatrogenic contamination of the PICC with bowel flora (e.g., due to inadequate hand hygiene, contamination of parenteral nutrition modules) is also unlikely to be the cause of this patient's CRBSI given the absence of CRBSIs due to bowel flora in other patients at the hospital. This patient's history suggests medical child abuse, also known as factitious disorder by proxy, which involves the exaggeration, falsification, or induction of illness in a child by a caregiver, resulting in the child receiving unnecessary medical care. Some commonly reported examples include contaminating medical equipment or samples, inducing vomiting or diarrhea, injecting poisons or infectious material into a venous line, and suffocating a child to induce apneic episodes. Diagnosis of medical child abuse requires a high level of suspicion. Red flags include an atypical illness course, infections by atypical organisms without a plausible explanation, and clinical deterioration that occurs just before discharge. Having an underlying medical illness does not rule out a diagnosis of medical child abuse, as up to 30% of affected children have a medical condition unrelated to the one being fabricated or induced by the caregiver.

It is necessary to urgently consult a child abuse specialist, typically through a child protection team within a hospital setting. Confronting the caregiver directly might put the child at risk for further, possibly greater, harm. The specialist will be able to guide the team on the best ways to immediately protect the child. Recommendations may include safety measures such as one-to-one staffing and close monitoring by an experienced provider staying at the bedside, or transferring the patient to the hospital’s pediatric intensive care unit to separate them from their caregiver. The specialist also can assist in reviewing records and reporting to child protective services. Seeking additional records from outside healthcare providers and institutions is important because victims of medical child abuse have often been evaluated at multiple locations. Consultation with psychiatry and legal professionals is also recommended.

C) INCORRECT:

Enteral nutrition via percutaneous access (e.g., with a gastrojejunostomy tube) is only indicated if nutritional support is anticipated for approx. > 4 weeks.

D) INCORRECT:

Bowel flora is responsible for this patient's polymicrobial bloodstream infection (BSI) but the culture results indicate a primary BSI (with the PICC being the source of infection) rather than a secondary BSI (e.g., due to occult bowel perforation).

E) INCORRECT:

Although recurrent bacteremia can be due to an underlying immunodeficiency, in this case, central line contamination is the underlying cause of sepsis.
questions.hint: A catheter-related bloodstream infection (CRBSI) is confirmed if the same organisms are grown from the catheter and venipuncture samples, and the differential time to positivity is > 120 minutes or the catheter culture has ≥ 3 times the number of colony-forming units as the venipuncture culture.
